user.biography:
A global collection, of and for Boston. The MFA welcomes you to explore more than 100 galleries of art, from ancient to contemporary.
📷 #mfaBoston

node.text:
Over a six-month period, artist and educator @chanelthervil met virtually with young Boston-area artists, facilitating discussions and art-making activities that focused on creating visual patterns to affirm their life experiences and capacity for greatness. Their collaborative project is now on view in our Linde Family Wing for Contemporary Art!

"Patterns of Greatness" marks the 16th year of the Community Arts Initiative, through which the MFA partners with community organizations to introduce young people ages 6 to 12 to the Museum’s collection and the art-making process.

node.title: Community Arts Initiative: Patterns of Greatness

node.text:
We're so moved to hear how much "Writing the Future: Basquiat and the #HipHopGeneration" means to Boston ❤️ ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🎟️ Experience it yourself—the exhibition has been extended through July, and May tickets are now on sale! Plan your visit via the link in our bio.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
📽️: @otbagency @gvanimusic @omrivisions

node.text:
Want the inside story on "#Monet and Boston?" Hear from staff who worked on the exhibition: curators Katie Hanson (@_katie_hanson_) and Sarah Thompson, archivist Maureen Melton and designer Chelsea Garunay (@chelsea_garunay).⁣
⁣
📺 The full feature is available on MFA Selects, our new platform for on-demand videos. Rent via the link in our bio!

node.text:
As 2020 comes to a close, we're looking back at one of our favorite memories from this year: a visit from Futura (@futuradosmil/@futuralaboratories), whose work is featured in our exhibition "Writing the Future: Basquiat and the #HipHopGeneration." In November, Futura joined co-curator @lizmunsell for a tour of the exhibition 👑

🎥: @filmsbeyondmeasure

node.title: Futura: A Visit to the Past

node.text: Created by @filmsbeyondmeasure, this documentary follows MFA artists-in-residence @problak and @robstull24, capturing their insights into creativity and street art. Gibbs and Stull collaborated with local youth for “The Mural Project,” a venture inspired by “Writing the Future: Basquiat and the #HipHopGeneration.”

node.text:
In this virtual edition of the Nancy Lee Clark Sound Bites Concert Series, contemporary classical violinist @lilithartunian performs pieces by three composers who were active during Claude #Monet's lifetime: S. C. Eckhardt-Gramatté, Erik Satie and Claude Debussy 🎻⁣
⁣
Originally filmed in May 2020, the concert was inspired by our exhibition "Monet and Boston: Lasting Impression" and features an introduction by exhibition curator Katie Hanson.

node.text:
Our new Huntington Avenue Entrance banners mark the first time in the MFA's history that work by a Boston artist has been featured on the Museum's façade. Here, artist-in-residence Rob Stull (@robstull24) describes the "mind-blowing" experience and his inspirations.⁣
⁣
📺 Want to learn more about Rob? While the Museum is temporarily closed, join us this Friday, December 18 to watch "Co-Sign," screening at 7 pm on our YouTube (link in bio). The documentary by @filmsbeyondmeasure follows Rob and his fellow MFA artist-in-residence @problak as they embark on "The Mural Project," inspired by our exhibition "Writing the Future: Basquiat and the #HipHopGeneration."

node.text:
This year marks the 15th year of our Community Arts Initiative, through which we partner with local after-school organizations to introduce kids ages 6 to 12 to the Museum's collection and the art-making process 🎉 

For the 2020 Community Arts Initiative Artist Project, Sarah Pollman (@sarahkpollman) collaborated with young artists to create a large-scale, wall-hung relief sculpture that charts global exchange pathways of the goods, services and ideas of artists.

See their final piece when "Community Arts Initiative: Exchange Codes" opens on November 11—the exhibition is included in general admission!

⁣
🎥: Ty Ueda (@batoutofhellbymeatloaf)

node.text:
Boston, we can't wait to share "Writing the Future: Basquiat and the #HipHopGeneration" with you 👑 

Earlier this year, we convened musicians, artists, educators, academics, financiers, social workers and creative professionals through our new Table of Voices initiative. At a series of roundtables and gatherings, they discussed Jean-Michel #Basquiat's impact on their lives and work—and his influence in shaping hip-hop culture in our city.

We're deeply grateful for this group's contributions to the exhibition’s interpretation, outreach and programming: Khamari Anderson, Chris Barnes, Kristen Catlin, Shaka Dendy (@shakadendy), Shaumba Dibinga, Rahn Dorsey, Niki DuFauchard, Ed O.G., Lisa Finelli Fallon, Murray Forman, Kerry Foster, Rob (@problak) Gibbs, Daren Graves, Tim Hall (@tv_hall), Leroy Irvin (@bostonlirvin), Stacy Lewis, Oompa (@oompoutloud), Moe Pope (@moepope), REKS (Corey Isiah Christie), DJ Riobamba (@riobamba_dj), Greg Shell, Tyrone Smith, Justin Springer, Rob Stull (@robstull24), Billy Dean Thomas (@billydeanthomas), Kris N. Tyler, Aysha Upchurch (@ayshadances), C Wells and DeJongh Dee Wells.

"Writing the Future" opens to the public on October 18!

node.text: A multi-instrumentalist, @gracegivertz uses her honest lyrics to bring a refreshing sound to folk. In this edition of our Nancy Lee Clark Sound Bites Concert Series, the Boston-based singer-songwriter performs original songs chosen in response to artworks from our exhibition “Women Take the Floor.” Givertz is introduced by Layla Bermeo, Kristin and Roger Servison Associate Curator of American Paintings.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Museum of Fine Arts, Boston on July 31, 2021. May be an image of flower and nature.

node.text:
This week the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) turns 31! If you've visited our "Garden for Boston," you may have spotted our newest accessibility improvement 👀

This ramp is one of two that are ADA compliant and will remain long after the garden is gone. It will allow many people for whom the six-inch curb was a barrier to have consistent access to the Huntington lawn for the first time.

[Image description: Poured concrete ramp leading into a sunflower garden. The ramp is pale grey and ends at a crushed stone pathway which runs through the garden, sunflowers in full bloom. Behind the flowers is the wall of the Museum and two skyscrapers in the distance.]

Whether they’re your best girlfriends, loyal guy friends, or furry, four-footed friends, they’re always the ones who make you laugh louder, smile brighter and live better 💛 #InternationalFriendshipDay

© Valerie Gerrard Browne

"Jarrell’s intense depiction of Angela Davis is as strong as her voice itself."

—Tariq Charles, Curator and Senior at Boston Adult Technical Academy (@bps.bata)

See "Revolutionary (Angela Davis)" (1972) by Wadsworth A. Jarrell on view in "Black Histories, Black Futures," an exhibition curated by teen scholars from @bam_boston and @_thebase.

[Image description: Collage of words in vibrant pink, orange, yellow and purple that depict Angela Davis speaking into a microphone]

Escaping this crazy weather in a dark, cool movie theater? 🍿 Tell us what films are on your list this summer!⁣

We'll start: @black.widow 🕷️ 🕸️ ⁣
⁣

⁣
© VAGA, New York, NY⁣
⁣
[Image description: Black-and-white print of a spider]

node.text:
The four-headed goddess at the center of this painting is Maha Pratisara. She is one of the Pancha Raksha, a group of five Tibetan Buddhist female deities that are known as the “Five Protectors.” ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
The yellow, red, green and blue figures in the box nearest to her represent the other four protector goddesses, while the many divinities in the outer registers of the painting are buddhas, planetary deities and more. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
At the bottom left is a figure seated in front of a shrine: this is the donor of the painting who, in sponsoring its making, was seeking to secure health, wealth and long life.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
🎨: "Pancha Raksha" (Tibet, mid-15th century), distemper on cotton
